headline: Europium
text: This week, we meet the rare earths element, europium, which has the atomic number 63 and the symbol Eu. Europium is a silvery-coloured element that is ductile. It also is highly reactive since its outer (valence) electron shell is half-filled, so this metal typically loses three electrons, adopting the +3 oxidation state (although you can also find it in the +2 oxidation state). Due to its high reactivity, europium is not found as a pure element in nature.   Europium is a wonderful element if you enjoy brilliant colours. In its typical trivalent (Eu3+) state, europium emits a brilliant red light when illuminated, which led to its use in cathode ray tubes (CRT) in television screens so we could enjoy the red uniforms that our favourite sports teams wear.  In its divalent (Eu2+) state, europium emits blue light when illuminated. A mineral, known as "Blue John" discovered in Derbyshire in the midlands of England, is a special form of calcium fluorite, CaF, that has the peculiar quality of emitting blue light when exposed to UV. For this reason, this quality was named "fluorescence", but only much later was it discovered that Blue John's fluorescence is actually due to trace amounts of europium, not fluoride.  Although the main consumer of europium, CRTs, is going the way of the dinosaur, europium still has other important uses. For example, since europium was named for Europe, it somehow seems fitting that it is used in euro bank notes to prevent forgeries. Divalent and trivalent europium also is used in low-energy light bulbs (trichromatic lamps) to provide both the red and the blue components of light, and now it's being used in sodium street lamps to provide lighting that is more natural, instead of that familiar hideous yellow colour.  Interestingly, europium is relatively abundant in samples of moon rocks. But unlike europium found on Earth, the europium originating from Moon rocks is more commonly in the +2 oxidation state. This suggests that the Moon came from a different source of cosmic material than did Earth.
